Silica-supported non-precious copper catalyst for catalytic hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan Xiaoting Zhu Investigation Methodology Data curation Writing – original draft a 1 Feng Wang Investigation Methodology Formal analysis a 1 Li Yang Validation a Zhouhuan Chen Formal analysis a Kangyu Zhao Visualization a Xianxiang Liu Conceptualization Methodology Project administration Funding acquisition Supervision a b ⁎ Qiong Xu Writing – review & editing a Dulin Yin Resources a Ningya Yu Resources Supervision a b ⁎ a National & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources, Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province, Hunan Normal University, Changsha 410081, China National & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province Hunan Normal University Changsha 410081 China aNational & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources, Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province, Hunan Normal University, Changsha 410081, China b Guangzhou Lingwe Technology Co., Ltd, Guangzhou 511400, China Guangzhou Lingwe Technology Co., Ltd Guangzhou 511400 China bGuangzhou Lingwe Technology Co., Ltd, Guangzhou 511400, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 These authors contributed equally. The selective hydroconversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is of great scientific and strategic significance for high-value utilization of biomass. Furandiols are important monomers for producing novel bio-based polyester, which can be prepared by HMF processing. In this work, a facile solid-phase grinding technique was employed to synthesize Cu/SiO2 catalysts, demonstrating outstanding catalytic performance for the selective hydrogenation of HMF to produce 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF). Remarkably, under conditions of 140 ℃ and 0.5 MPa H2 for 6 h, a HMF conversion of 99.0 % and a BHMF yield of 94.7 % were achieved. Multiple characterization techniques, including transmission electron microscopy (TEM), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm techniques, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were utilized and revealed the relationship between catalyst properties and its structure. The findings indicated that Cu+ can adsorb and activate the carbonyl group (C=O), while Cu0 is responsible for H2 dissociation, culminating in the efficient hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF through the synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu0. This kind of non-precious copper catalyst presents significant potential for industrial-scale applications. Introduction As industries continue to develop and advance, there is an escalating demand for fossil fuels among people. Nevertheless, being a non-renewable resource, the continual depletion of fossil fuel reserves has heightened researchers' focus on seeking viable substitutes [1–8]. Biomass, being a novel and environmentally friendly form of renewable energy, holds significant promise in assuming a crucial role in the substitution of fossil fuels. Its emergence signifies a pivotal step towards transitioning to sustainable energy sources and reducing reliance on non-renewable resources like fossil fuels. In particular, the use of biomass route to prepare fine chemical products is of great significance. Obtained through the hydrolysis of glucose and other monosaccharide compounds, 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) represents a crucial biomass-derived chemical, featuring functional groups such as carbonyl (C=O), hydroxymethyl (-CHOH) and a carbon-carbon double bond (C=C) functional groups [9–13]. The selective conversion of HMF is an important part of high value utilization of biomass resources and has important research value. Owing to these active functional groups, HMF can undergo hydrogenation to yield various high-value derivatives, including 2,5-dihydroxymethylfuran (BHMF), 2,5-dihydroxymethyltetrahydrofuran (BHMTHF), 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF), 2,5-Furandicarboxylicacid (FDCA), 2, 5-diformylfuran (DFF). These furan derivatives are used to synthesize fuels, polymers and solvents, which have great application in production life [14–16]. Among many furan intermediates, BHMF, with its unique hydroxymethyl symmetrical structure, is a biobased material that can be widely used to synthesize important biodegradable materials. In addition, BHMF can also be used to synthesize drugs [17,18], crown ether, ketones, polyesters [19], resins [20,21] and artificial fibers [22], of which polyester is one of the most versatile polymers, and the double bond in BHMF enhances the stability of the polyester, which has led to a large number of applications in plastics, elastomers, coatings, plasticizers, etc. [23]. It is a great challenge for us because both hydrogenation products and hydrogenolysis products are generated during the preparation of BHMF from HMF, and the complexity of products makes it difficult to obtain high yields of BHMF (Scheme 1 ). In recent years, researchers have done much work on selective hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF, mainly focusing on noble metals. Balakrishnan et al. obtained an 85.0 % yield of BHMF by using Pt supported on Al2O3 (Pt/Al2O3) catalyst in the HMF selective hydrogenation reaction at 1.4 MPa H2 and 333 K for 18 h, but the excessively long reaction time seriously limited the actual production and subsequent application of BHMF [24]. Mariappan et al. prepared Ru-decorated porous melamine polymer (Ru/PMFH) catalyst for the hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF and achieved 90.0 % conversion of HMF and 89.1 % yield of BHMF at 323 K for 8 h in an aqueous phase. However, this reaction requires 2 MPa H2, and the use of such high hydrogen pressure requires more delicate and expensive equipment, and there are huge safety risks during transportation and use [25]. Dinesh et al. designed Manganese and cobalt metals-based mixed oxide spinels supported ruthenium (Ru/MnCo2O4) catalyst and obtained 100 % conversion of HMF and BHMF has a yield of 98.5 % under the condition of 373 K and 16 h with the hydrogen pressure of 8.2 MPa. However, too severe reaction conditions were not conducive to industrial production [26]. Kseniia et al. used platinum supported on ceria−zirconia mixed oxide (Pt/CZ) catalyst to react at 298 K with H2 pressure of 0.5 MPa for 6 h, and BHMF has a yield of 87.0 %. However, due to the scarcity of resources, precious metals are often very expensive [27,28]. Therefore, it is imperative to research and produce cheaper and more efficient non-precious metal catalysts. Non-precious metal catalysis has been studied by researchers and some progress has been made in the selective hydrogenation of HMF to prepare BHMF. For example, Yao et al. prepared the Co-Al mixed oxide catalyst using a simple preparation method, which can obtain an 83.0 % yield of BHMF at 4 MPa hydrogen pressure, 393 K, and 4 h [29]. Brzezińska et al. used CuZnO catalyst to catalyze HMF hydrogenation, and the 92.0 % yield of BHMF could be obtained by reaction at 493 K and 3 MPa hydrogen for 5 h [30]. The copper-alumina (CA) catalysts was prepared by Rao et al. for HMF selective hydrogenation reaction, which can obtain 100 % conversion of HMF and 93.0 % yield of BHMF at 373 K and 2 MPa hydrogen pressure [31]. Ahishakiye et al. obtained an 93.9 % yield of BHMF by using Co-CoOx-10FeNiCo/γ-Al2O3 catalyst at 2 MPa H2, 423 K, and 7 h [32]. High hydrogen pressure and reaction temperature put forward high technical requirements for production equipment and increase safety risks. Overcoming the challenge of achieving selective hydrogenation of HMF under milder conditions remains a pressing issue. In this study, we have prepared a series of catalysts using a green solid phase grinding method [33]. Compared with the traditional metal catalyst preparation process, this method does not require additional hydrogen gas, and utilizes the reducing gas generated by the copper citrate complex at high temperature to reduce the metal, which is safe and easy to operate, as well as being greener and more environmentally friendly. During the experiments, we investigated the effects of different Cu loadings during catalyst preparation, hydrogen pressure, reaction temperature, time as well as the catalyst dosage in the HMF hydrogenation reaction. The experiments showed that the selective hydrogenation of HMF for the preparation of BHMF could be realized by using Cu/SiO2 catalyst in relatively moderate conditions. Experimental Materials Cupric nitrate trihydrate (99.7 %), citric acid monohydrate (99.7 %), tetrahydrofuran (THF) (99.7 %) and octane all from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. SiO2 was supplied by Guangzhou Lingwei Technology Co., Ltd. 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (98.0 %) was purchased from Shanghai D&B Biological Science and Technology Co. Ltd. 2,5-Bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (98.0 %), 5-methyl-2-furanmethanol (95.0 %), and 5-methyl furfural (98.0 %) all from Shanghai Bidepharm Technology Co., Ltd. Catalyst preparations For the preparation of Cu/SiO2 catalysts, we use the grinding method. Firstly, copper nitrate trihydrate (1.42 mmol, 0.34 g) and citric acid monohydrate (1.68 mmol, 0.35 g) were weighed and added to the mortar at the same time and ground to a paste. Then silica was added for further grinding for 1 h. When grinding, I would add a small amount of water to encourage the formation of a paste. Transfer the paste from the mortar to a beaker, it was dried in an oven for 10 h at a drying temperature of 120 °C. At the end of drying, the precursor was transferred from the beaker to the mortar and was well ground. Next, the precursors were put into test tubes and calcined in a tube furnace. The calcination temperature is 375 °C, the heating rate is 3 °C/min, the calcination time is 3 h, and the atmosphere is nitrogen. Finally, the Cu/SiO2 catalyst with 10 % Cu loading was obtained, which was denoted as 10 % Cu/SiO2. To facilitate comparison, we used the same method to prepare 1 %, 3 %, 5 % and 15 % Cu/SiO2 catalysts. Characterization TG-DTA is a thermogravimetric analysis-differential thermal analysis method, mainly used to analyze whether the thermal stability of the material is good or not. In this experiment, the NETZSCH TG 209F1 Libra device was used to perform TG-DTA analysis. X-ray diffraction (XRD) is a non-destructive material technique in which X-rays are diffracted from a material and the diffraction pattern is analyzed to obtain information about the material's main composition and crystal structure. XRD was examined by Rigaku SmartLab SE with the following test parameters: Cu target, scanning range of 5 ° to 90 °, and scanning speed of 10 °/min. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm techniques were measured with Micromeritics ASAP 2460 sorption analyzer, and the specific surface area and pore size distribution of the material can be calculated using the equation. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) allows qualitative, quantitative or semi-quantitative and valence analysis of the elemental composition of solid samples using Thermo Scientific K-Alpha equipment with Al Kα rays (hv=1486.6 eV) as the excitation source, a spot size of 400 μm, an operating voltage of 12 kV and a filament current of 6 mA for analysis. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was used to observe the internal fine structure morphology of the sample with FEI Tecnai G2 F20. Fourier transform infrared spectra (FT-IR) using Thermo Fisher Niolet iN10 equipment with 4 cm−1 resolution, 32 scans, and a wave number range of 400–4000 cm−1. Catalytic testing Weighing 0.126 g of HMF (1 mmol), 0.050 g of 10 % Cu/SiO2, 0.057 g n-octane (0.5 mmol) and 10 ml of tetrahydrofuran (THF) and then filled into Teflon liner with a volume of 50 ml. Then placed into an autoclave made of stainless steel, and drained the air from the equipment by three passes of nitrogen, followed by hydrogen to drain the previous nitrogen, and then inject a moderate amount of hydrogen, and finally it is placed on a thermostatic magnetic stirrer to start stirring and heating, and the temperature and pressure changes were monitored during the reaction. When the reaction is complete, the reactor is transferred to cold water and allowed to cool to room temperature before sampling with a syringe with a filter membrane. For catalysts in solution that needed to be reused, it was separated by centrifugation, after which they were cleaned with tetrahydrofuran and dried under vacuum. The separated samples were analyzed using a Shimadzu gas chromatography (GC-2030) with a capillary column model SH-Rtx-1701. Determination of retention times using pure substances, using octane as an internal standard, calculated by the internal standard method. The formula is as follows. HMF conversion ( % ) = 1 − Mole of HMF Initial mole of HMF × 100 % BHMF selectivity ( % ) = Mole of BHMF Initial mole of HMF − mole of HMF × 100 % BHMF yield ( % ) = Mole of BHMF Initial mole of HMF × 100 % Results and discussion Characterization of catalysts The results regarding the XRD spectra of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 . The characteristic peak of amorphous SiO2 at 2θ=23.3 ° and its persistence after the addition of copper proves that the silica structure is well preserved [34]. No significant CuO diffraction peaks were observed in all catalysts, from which it can be assumed that the amount of Cu2+ in the catalysts is small or they are all reduced to Cu+ and Cu0 species, which needs to be verified by subsequent characterization. Diffraction peaks observed at 36.42° (111) (PDF#05–0667) are consistent across all Cu/SiO2 catalysts, except in the case of the 1 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst, where they are attributed to Cu2O [35]. The diffraction peak of Cu at 43.30 ◦ (111), 50.43 ◦ (200), and 74.13 ◦ (220) (PDF#04–0836) can be observed obviously with the increase of Cu content [36]. As for the Cu2O phase in the catalyst, it is reasonable to assume that it is the incomplete reduction of the citric acid complex under a nitrogen atmosphere. The catalyst was characterized by X-Ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) to further understand the chemical nature and composition. In Fig. 2a , the peak at 952.5 and 932.7 eV correspond to Cu 2p1/2 and Cu 2p3/2. No obvious satellite peaks were observed between 940 and 945 eV, demonstrating that all Cu2+ species were reduced to Cu+ or Cu0 [37]. Since the binding energies of Cu+ and Cu0 are very near to each other, XPS measurements alone are not sufficient to distinguish between them. For this purpose, we made another measurement called Auger electron spectroscopy (AES), which can characterize Cu LM2 spectra. In Fig. 2b, the 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst contains both Cu+ and Cu0 with binding energies of 573.5 and 570.2 eV, according to the above XRD results. In Fig. 2c, the peak of 284.8 eV belongs to the CC species, which had a carbon peak correction. Besides, the two peaks at 286.5 and 288.7 eV are C-O and O=C-O, respectively. The C 1 s in the XPS curves indicate the presence of residual carbon compounds from the incompletely decomposed copper citrate complex in the 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst. In Fig. 2d, the binding energy of Si-O and Cu-O species are about 533.2 and 531.1 eV respectively [38]. The XPS characterization of the Cu/SiO2 catalysts with different copper contents can explain the difference in catalytic effect of the catalysts. Through Fig. 3 and Fig . 2b, it can be clearly observed that as the Cu loading increases from 1 % to 15 %, the peak area of Cu0 gradually increases, that is, the content of Cu0 increases. When the load of Cu reaches 10 %, the peak area of Cu+ and Cu0 is equal, and the ratio is about 1. When the load of Cu is increased to 15 %, the result is unchanged from 10 %. Thus, we can roughly infer that the different catalytic effects of catalysts with different Cu loads may be due to the different contents of Cu+ and Cu0, and the catalytic effect is best when Cu0/Cu+ is 1. Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) was used to detect the internal fine structure of the Cu/SiO2 catalyst. In Fig. 4a , the spherical SiO2 structure can be seen. As shown in Fig. 4b-f, a large number of copper species were dispersed on SiO2 in the Cu/SiO2 catalyst, indicating that the catalyst preparation was successful. In addition, with the increase of Cu content in the catalyst, the agglomeration phenomenon is more obvious. At a low content such as 1 %, the amount of Cu is small and the agglomeration is not much, and the corresponding catalytic effect is poor; at a high content such as 10 %, the amount of Cu is large and the agglomeration is also increased, and the corresponding catalytic effect is superb; when the content is increased to 15 %, the agglomeration phenomenon is greatly increased, resulting in a decrease in the catalytic effect. In Fig. 3h, the lattice fringes with the crystal plane spacing of 0.2065 and 0.2445 nm are observed on the SiO2 surface, which belongs to the Cu (111) and Cu2O (111) crystal planes, respectively, which are consistent with the XPS results [39]. Using FT-IR measurement to understand the structure of Cu/SiO2 catalyst. In Fig. 5 , the broad peak at 3443 cm−1 and the sharp peak at 1632 cm−1 are bending vibrations of the HO-H bond, which is physically adsorbed water. Additionally, as shown in Fig. 5, three peaks of 1100, 803, and 468 cm−1 can be observed, which are all attributed to the vibration of the Si-O bond in amorphous SiO2 [40,41]. Based on this, it can be inferred that the crystal structure of SiO2 was well preserved during the catalyst preparation. Thermogravimetric Analysis (TG) was performed on the 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst. Only about 9 % of the mass is lost in the range from 30 to 800 ℃ in Fig. 6 . At 30–170 ℃, there is a 5 % mass loss, which is the removal of physically adsorbed water and water of crystallization from the 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst. At 170–350 ℃, there is about 2 % mass loss, which is the decomposition of some uncomplexed copper nitrate and citric acid in the catalyst. Between 350 and 450 ℃, the 1 % mass loss is the decomposition of copper citrate complex [42]. Based on the above analysis, it can be proved that the catalyst has good thermal stability. To understand some of the physical properties of the 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst, we conducted nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherm experiments on SiO2 and 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalysts. In Table 1 , the BET surface area, pore diameter and pore volume can be seen. The specific surface area, pore diameter and pore volume of SiO2 decreased after loading with Cu, which indicated that the preparation of 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst was successful and some Cu species covered the surface of SiO2 and entered into the SiO2 pores. The nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms for the 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst are in Fig. 7 , and the inset shows the pore size distribution of the catalyst. The catalyst has type IV isotherm characteristics, and the H1 hysteresis loop appears when the relative pressure is between 0.5 and 1.0, which indicates that the catalyst is a mesoporous material [43]. This mesoporous structure is beneficial to the mass transfer process of HMF hydrogenation. Selective hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF Effect of the Cu loading A batch of Cu/SiO2 catalysts with different Cu loads was prepared by the same method, and they were used in HMF hydrogenation to BHMF reaction. The results obtained are shown in Table 2 . For the two catalysts 1 % Cu/SiO2 and 3 % Cu/SiO2, after 24 h of reaction, their catalytic effects are not ideal, and the Turnover Frequency (TOF) values obtained by calculation are 0.28 h−1 and 0.55 h−1 respectively. The reason may be that the small Cu load makes it difficult to provide a sufficient number of active sites for the reaction. Using 5 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst to catalyze HMF hydrogenation reaction, the yield of BHMF reached 58.6% in 8 h, and the TOF value increased to 1.56 h−1. For 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the yield of BHMF reached 43.3 % and the TOF value was 3.09 h−1 in 1.5 h. Compared with 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst, the yield of BHMF is 41.0% and the TOF value decreased to 1.46 h−1 by using 15 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst in 2 h. According to the results of XRD, XPS and TEM characterization, it is speculated that the large load may lead to the poor dispersion of Cu on the SiO2 support, and the agglomeration phenomenon occurs, which reduces the number of available active sites in the reaction. In addition, too many Cu particles may lead to the blockage of the SiO2 pore, affecting the mass transfer process of the reaction. Effects of the reaction condition The temperature has a great influence on the distribution of HMF hydrogenation products, and the results are shown in Fig. 8a . When the reaction temperature was changed from 100 ℃ to 140 ℃, the HMF conversion increased from 33.2 % to 87.7 %, and the BHMF selectivity only decreased by 1 %. These results suggest that HMF hydrogenation was the main reaction pathway at low temperatures. When the reaction temperature raised to 180 ℃, the conversion of HMF continued to rise until it reached 90.7 % at 180 ℃. The BHMF selectivity also reduced from 93.4 % to 69.9 %, whereas the selectivity of by-products 2,5-dimethylfuran (DMF) and 5-Methyl furfural (5-MF) increased. This suggests that increasing temperature favors the hydrogenolysis process of HMF. Therefore, 140℃ was chosen as a suitable temperature for HMF selective hydrogenation to prepare BHMF. By exploring the reaction time, we can better understand the reaction path of HMF selective hydrogenation to BHMF. In Fig. 8b, after reacting for 1 h, the HMF conversion was only 42.6 %, and the selectivity of BHMF was 97.2 %. It is shown that at the beginning of the reaction, HMF is immediately converted to BHMF as soon as it is generated. After 6 h of reaction, it was observed that the HMF conversion steadily raised to 99.0 %, while the selectivity of BHMF was almost unchanged. Through the above results, we found that a 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst has a good hydrogenation effect on C=O in HMF, and it is not easy to occur excessive hydrogenation phenomenon, and the hydrogenolysis products are few [44]. According to previous reports, we hypothesized that Cu+ can adsorb and activate the carbonyl group (C=O), while Cu0 is responsible for H2 dissociation. The efficient hydrogenation of HMF to produce BHMF is due to the synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu0 [45]. Hydrogen pressure cannot be ignored in reactions using hydrogen as a hydrogen source, as shown in Fig. 8c. At an H2 pressure of 0.1 MPa, HMF conversion was 52.2 %, and the selectivity of BHMF was 92.0 %. Low H2 pressure could not make HMF complete conversion. At a H2 pressure of 0.5 MPa, HMF conversion was 99.0 % and BHMF selectivity was 95.7 %. The selectivity of the by-product 5-MF was only 3.5 %. At the appropriate H2 pressure, HMF was almost completely converted, giving mainly the hydrogenation product BHMF and little 5-MF. When we continued to increase the H2 pressure to 1 MPa, HMF could be completely converted, but the selectivity of BHMF decreased slightly and the by-product 5-MF increased. It can be seen that when the H2 pressure is too high, it will promote the hydrogenolysis of HMF. Therefore, 0.5 MPa was chosen as a more appropriate H2 pressure for this reaction. The influence of catalyst dosage was studied from the perspective of green economy. When the dosage of the catalyst is 20 mg, the conversion of HMF is 34.4 %, and the selectivity of BHMF is 95.8 %. At this point, a small amount of catalyst could not provide sufficient active sites to transform HMF completely. The conversion of HMF raised to 73.8 % and the selectivity of BHMF remained almost unchanged when the catalyst dosage was increased to 40 mg. When the catalyst dosage is 60 mg, the conversion of HMF is 99.7 %, which is almost completely converted, and the BHMF selectivity is still stable. The above results have obvious regularity, the conversion of HMF and catalyst dosage showed a positive correlation, while the selectivity of BHMF did not change significantly. This is because as the amount of catalyst increases, the number of active sites increases and the reaction becomes more complete. Proposed reaction mechanism Through analysis of the experimental data and characterization results, we have elucidated the mechanism for the hydrogenation of HMF to BHMF in the presence of the 10 % Cu/SiO2 catalyst Scheme 2 ). Firstly, an interaction occurs between the electron deficient Cu+ species and the lone pair of electrons of the aldehyde oxygen, through which the substrate HMF is adsorbed on the surface of Cu+ while H2 is adsorbed on Cu0. The hydrogen molecule is dissociated, and the resulting reactive hydrogen atoms actively attack the carbonyl carbon, and the C=O bond is broken [46,47]. And then, another active hydrogen goes on to hydrogenate to get BHMF. Finally, BHMF is desorbed from the surface of Cu+ species. The results indicate that the efficient hydrogenation of HMF to produce BHMF is due to the synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu0 [48,49]. The performance of the prepared Cu/SiO2 catalysts was compared with that of non-precious metal catalysts that have been reported in the literature (Table S1), and it was observed that our catalysts gave very excellent effect for the preparation of BHMF by hydrogenation with HMF under relatively mild conditions. Conclusions The silica-supported non-precious copper catalyst was prepared using a green solid-phase grinding method, followed by an in-situ reduction utilizing the reducing gas generated from the Cu-citric acid complex at elevated temperatures. The catalyst was used in the HMF hydrogenation reaction, and 99.0 % HMF conversion and 94.7 % BHMF yield were achieved under relatively mild conditions. Characterization revealed that the presence of both Cu0 and Cu+ species in the catalyst. In the reaction, Cu+ can adsorb and activate the carbonyl group, while Cu0 is responsible for H2 dissociation. The synergistic interaction between Cu+ and Cu0 promotes HMF transformation. This efficient and inexpensive catalyst can be widely used in industrial production, which is conducive to promoting the development of non-precious metal catalysts in the biomass industry. coredata.dc:description: The selective hydroconversion of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is of great scientific and strategic significance for high-value utilization of biomass. Furandiols are important monomers for producing novel bio-based polyester, which can be prepared by HMF processing. In this work, a facile solid-phase grinding technique was employed to synthesize Cu/SiO2 catalysts, demonstrating outstanding catalytic performance for the selective hydrogenation of HMF to produce 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan (BHMF). Remarkably, under conditions of 140 ℃ and 0.5 MPa H2 for 6 h, a HMF conversion of 99.0 % and a BHMF yield of 94.7 % were achieved. Multiple characterization techniques, including transmission electron microscopy (TEM), N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm techniques, X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were utilized and revealed the relationship between catalyst properties and its structure. The findings indicated that Cu+ can adsorb and activate the carbonyl group (C=O), while Cu0 is responsible for H2 dissociation, culminating in the efficient hydrogenation of HMF into BHMF through the synergistic effect of Cu+ and Cu0. This kind of non-precious copper catalyst presents significant potential for industrial-scale applications.
coredata.dc:title: Silica-supported non-precious copper catalyst for catalytic hydrogenation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-bis(hydroxymethyl)furan
